items.name: Sputnik Case Study
items.synopsis: For one of my university applications, I was given the task to create a 10 minute presentation about anything VFX related. I decided to focus on Sputnik, and how realistic muscle/tissue based creatures are made.
items.description: This project was a new experience for me as I had to dive heavily into the Houdini documentation and learn how to properly research and experiment.

items.name: Full Animation
items.description: The full project took about a month to create.

items.name: Presentation
items.description: This is a full recording of one my practice presentations.

items.name: Sputnik Skin Model
items.description: I'm especially proud of how well I was able to the match references of the original character.

items.name: Houdini Character
items.description: The Houdini nodes for the muscle-tissue system of the character.

items.name: Houdini FX
items.description: The Houdini nodes for the fx systems of the character.

items.name: Nuke Composite
items.description: The Nuke nodes for compositing the final project. This was one of the first projects where I began to experiment with render passes.

items.name: The Girl and the Robot
items.synopsis: A girl discovers the importance of friendship through a robot she meets in the forest.
items.description: The Girl and the Robot (TGATR) is a short film that a friend and I have made in our final year of high school. We are both interested in film and our parents suggested we work together on our own movie. My one regret is giving myself 35 visual effects shots.
items.tools: Blender, Substance Painter, Nuke, Mocha, DaVinci Resolve

items.name: The Girl and the Robot
items.description: The complete short film. We spent around 1 month planning, 1 month filming, and then 10 months editing. The entire production took about a year.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: A sheet from the 70 page storyboard.

items.name: Character Concept
items.description: An early character concept of Chipp. I wanted to base him off the robot from Tales from the Loop (2020).

items.name: Filming
items.description: An on-set photo from one the dinner scenes. This was the first time that I had ever used lights in a shoot.

items.name: Chipp Turntable
items.description: A turntable animation of Chipp.

items.name: Chipp Sketchfab
items.description: An interactive model of Chipp.

items.name: Animation
items.description: A pre-rendered shot in the film.

items.name: Full VFX Shot
items.description: The same shot, but rendered and comped.

items.name: Nuke Comp
items.description: The compositing workflow for one of the more advanced scenes using Nuke. There is probably a much more efficient way to comp the shot, but it worked.

items.name: Fallout Shopping
items.synopsis: With humanity wiped from existence, a retail robot is finally free to enjoy what he loves most; going shopping!
items.description:
I came up with the idea for Fallout Shopping while at Central Festival in Chiang Mai. I saw a retail bot wandering around one of the shops, and I thought to myself 'What if that robot could explore the entire mall?' I then spent my summer in England planning out the story, and then animated the entire thing the following month.

Fallout Shopping was showcased at the 2022 Beyond Animation Festival in Bangkok.
items.role: Director, CG Artist, VFX Artist, Editor

items.name: Fallout Shopping
items.description: The full animation took just under 2 full months to make. 1 month for concepting and planning, another for production.

items.name: Synopsis
items.description: A synposis page that I threw together. This helped me determine whether or not I wanted to make Fallout Shopping.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: A video of the storyboard matched to the music. It helped me get my thoughts together and know how long each shot was going to be.

items.name: Concept 1
items.description: A concept page of how I wanted the scenes to look.

items.name: Concept 2
items.description: Another page of concepts. I based most of the scenes off Central Festival in Chiang Mai.

items.name: Concept 3
items.description: Another page of concepts. I never completed outdoor the environment because I thought I could wing it. It ended up being the worst shot in the entire animation.

items.name: Turntable
items.description: A turntable of the retail bot. I never gave him a name, he wasn't cool enough for that.

items.name: Retail Bot Sketchfab
items.description: An interactive model of the retail bot.

items.name: Lighting Test 1
items.description: An early lighting test of the opening shot. I struggled with trying to create a damaged apocalyptic floor.

items.name: Lighting Test 2
items.description: Another early lighting test. This shot gave experience on how to light a hallway with a strong backlight.

items.name: Lighting Test 3
items.description: This shot is what inspired me to make Fallout Shopping. I had imagined it weeks before I considered making it an animation.

items.name: Lamp Attack!
items.synopsis: We've all grown accustomed to the brutality we see in the Pixar intro. But what about those poor Pixar letters everywhere else?
items.description: I was eating lunch one day when I thought to myself 'What if the Pixar lamps were like monsters to the Pixar letters?' I had always wanted to make something horror inspired, and within a week I had a storyboard planned out for the animation.

items.name: Lamp Attack!
items.description: The entire short film. I was amazed that a dumb idea I had while eating lunch ended up becoming a full short animation.

items.name: Sketch
items.description: The first sketch. The entire animation was built off this one quick drawing.

items.name: Storyboard
items.description: This was the first time I made a storyboard for an entire short. As I was working in a team I wanted to show them what we were aiming for.

items.name: Rig
items.description: Rigging the letters was a fun experience for me. There were no tutorials online so my rigging ability was really put to the test.

items.name: Rig Demo
items.description: Rigging Luxo Jr. wasnt' as difficult to rig as there were numerous tutorials.

items.name: Early Animation Test
items.description: Early animation test. I started with just the core actors as I wanted them to look perfect in the final shot.

items.name: Lighting Test
items.description: A lighting test. I wanted the spotlight to be the main source of light as it would give off a more horror-like mood.

items.name: Crowd Test
items.description: Finding a way to animate large crowds was a huge challenge. Here's one of the failed crowd tests.

items.name: Pixar Intro
items.description: While testing the letter and Luxo rigs, I made a mock Pixar intro.

items.name: Sparky
items.synopsis: In a quest to find a new power source for Glenton, a robot finds himself doing more harm than good. Or so it seems...
items.description: Sparky was the only short film that was made by BOAP Studios. Although I was given the role of producer, I was heavily involved in writing, modelling, and animating. This was the first time that I got to work with other artists.

items.name: Sparky
items.description: The entire short film took about 16 months to make.

items.name: Early Concept
items.description: An early concept of Sparky. I thew this together as a test to see how his limbs would interact with the surroundings.

items.name: Street
items.description: A screenshot of the road scene. A lot of duplication and moving of houses was done for this.

items.name: Animation
items.description: A screenshot of Sparky during the animation phase. We went for more tube based limbs so we could stretch Sparky as much as we needed.

items.name: Turbines
items.description: An early shot of the turbines. The mountain was everntually removed from the shot but the rest of the scene is relatively similar to the final.

items.name: Warehouse
items.description: An interior image of the warehouse. Getting optimized render settings for this scene was extremely difficult due to the amount of render noise.

items.name: Breeze Render Engine
items.synopsis: Breeze Render Engine is a C++ application that allows artists to create scenes in OpenGL and then render them out with Breeze's custom render engine.
items.description: Built off the Ray Tracing in One Weekend tutorial series, Breeze Render Engine is my first ever C++, OpenGL, and Qt application. The project took around 8 months and there were numerous rewrites.

items.name: Scene Example
items.description: A screenshot of a scene made in Breeze. You can download and try the application from my Github page.

items.name: Demo Video
items.description: A demo video of Breeze in action.

items.name: OBJ Importing
items.description: Breeze also allows custom OBJ importing.

items.name: Render
items.description: The render from the demo video.

items.name: Sicle Maps App
items.synopsis: Sicle is a simplified alternative to Google Maps. Users can track their location and follow routes to their desired destination.
items.description:
After seeing some modern app designs on Dribbble, I was inspired to write my own mobile application. Since I'm an avid cyclist, I wanted to make an application that I could use. The solution was a simplified Google Maps application called Sicle.

The app was written in Kotlin using Android Studio, and relies on the Mapbox API.

items.name: App Screenshot
items.description: A screenshot of the app in use.

items.name: App Demo Video
items.description: The app runs on Android and uses the MapBox API.

items.name: Website
items.synopsis: I custom built this website! With HTML, CSS, Javascript and a lot of love, everything you see here was programmed by me.
items.description: I learnt the basics of web design in 2019, and have been using that knowledge in many of my web and Qt applications.
